pushFold.scenariosHint: Leave empty to include all scenarios
pushFold.referenceDesc: Push/Fold charts are based on Nash equilibrium ranges for tournament play. The correct decision depends on your stack size, position, and the action before you.

gtoPractice.title: GTO Practice Mode
gtoPractice.description: Practice preflop against a GTO AI opponent

tips.title: How to Play
tips.tip1: BTN vs BB heads-up preflop practice
tips.tip2: AI makes decisions based on GTO frequencies
tips.tip3: GTO advice shown after each hand
tips.tip4: Practice preflop strategy from different positions

multistreet.title: Multi-Street Drill
multistreet.description: Practice complete multi-street decisions from Flop to River
multistreet.villainCRPrompt: Villain check-raised your bet. How do you respond?
multistreet.tipPairedDesc: Strategy becomes more polarized, medium hands lose value

endless.title: Endless Drill
endless.description: Randomly practice all scenario types to sharpen your GTO instincts
endless.tipCorrectDesc: Actions with frequency ≥ 25% are considered correct
endless.tipMixedDesc: GTO typically requires mixing multiple actions, not just one correct answer
endless.tipPositionDesc: IP can play more aggressively, OOP needs more caution

squeeze.title: Squeeze Training
squeeze.tip1: Earlier opener position → stronger range → tighter squeeze needed
squeeze.tip2: Caller presence = more fold equity (dead money)
squeeze.tip3: Your position: SB needs to win pot more than BB (OOP disadvantage postflop)
squeeze.tip4: Hands with A blocker are better for squeeze (blocks AA/AK)
squeeze.shortcuts: Shortcuts: S = Squeeze, C = Call, F = Fold

reference.title: Squeeze Strategy Reference
reference.explanation: When a player opens and someone calls, you 3-bet to pressure both into folding. This leverages "dead money" (caller's chips) to increase fold equity.
reference.hand1: Premium hands (AA-TT, AK, AQ) — always squeeze
reference.hand2: A-blocker hands (A5s-A2s) — block opponent's strong combos
reference.hand3: Strong suited connectors (KQs, QJs, JTs) — have fallback equity
reference.sizingDesc: Standard squeeze size = open × 3 + 1 × each caller. Example: CO opens 2.5BB, BTN calls → Squeeze to 10-11BB.

flopTexture.title: Flop Texture Training
flopTexture.description: Learn to identify flop textures and master C-bet frequency and sizing

classify.cardDesc: Identify which of 12 texture types the flop belongs to
classify.question: What is this flop's texture?

cbet.cardDesc: Learn C-bet frequency and sizing for different textures
cbet.question: What frequency and sizing for C-bet?
cbet.explanation: {texture} board ({position}), recommended C-bet frequency ~{freqRange}, using {sizing} sizing.

threeLayer.cardDesc: Post-flop decision OS: Initiative → Volatility → Purpose
threeLayer.layer3: What is the purpose of betting?

initiative.question: Do you have initiative?
initiative.subtext: Does this flop still represent your preflop story?

volatility.question: Will the board change?
volatility.subtext: Could one turn card flip the dynamic?

purpose.question: What is the bet purpose?
purpose.subtext: Value / Deny equity / Bluff - pick one

s0.initiative: High card board represents your preflop story, clear range advantage
s0.volatility: Board is stable, most turns are blanks
s0.purpose: Small bet to deny opponent backdoor equity, collect toll
s0.action: High frequency small sizing (25-33%), almost entire range can bet

s1.initiative: Overwhelming range advantage, BB's strong hands mostly 3-bet preflop
s1.volatility: Straights possible, but PFR still dominates
s1.purpose: Large sizing for value + protection, BB can't fight back

s2.initiative: Range advantage exists but low card gives BB some connections
s2.volatility: Any high or connecting turn card can change dynamics
s2.purpose: Bet with made hands, mix sizings
s2.action: High frequency mixed sizing (33% range bet or selective 66%)

s3.initiative: Low board favors BB's calling range
s3.purpose: Unclear betting purpose = should not bet
s3.action: High frequency check, only bet with overpair or backdoor high cards

s4.initiative: Range advantage with opponent, they have more sets and two pair
s4.volatility: Explosive — many turn cards complete straights or flushes
s4.action: High frequency check on flop, only bet with strong made hands or combo draws

s5.initiative: Usually the preflop aggressor, opponent unlikely to have trips
s5.volatility: Board is stable, turn almost never changes things
s5.purpose: Thin value + deny, bluffing cost is low
s5.action: Small sizing high frequency, medium hands can extract over three streets

mustCheck.cardDesc: Learn when to check instead of betting
mustCheck.selfCheck: "I'm betting now because ___, and after being called I plan ___."
mustCheck.selfCheckTip: If you can't explain → Check = closest to GTO
mustCheck.question: Should this hand check?

cat.midWetAirDesc: On 987/865 boards, air with no backdoors or blockers
cat.lowBoardNoOverpairDesc: On 952r boards, high cards without overpair
cat.connectedWeakMadeDesc: On JT9 boards, small pairs should check-fold
cat.monotoneNoFlushDesc: On monotone boards without a flush
cat.broadwayNoBackdoorDesc: On AJT boards, weak hands without backdoor draws
cat.villainRangeAdvDesc: When the board clearly favors opponent
cat.oopWetBoardDesc: Out of position on wet boards, many hands should check
cat.protectCheckRangeDesc: Some strong hands should check to protect your check range
cat.turnWillChangeDesc: When turn is expected to dramatically change dynamics
cat.noClearPurposeDesc: Can't explain why betting = shouldn't bet

0.reason: On 987 boards, AK has no backdoors or blockers, should check directly

1.reason: Has backdoor flush draw, can be a bluff candidate

2.reason: On 952r board, AQ has no pair, unclear betting purpose

3.reason: TT is overpair, can bet for value

4.reason: On JT9 board, 99 is mid pair, almost always loses when called, should check

5.reason: JJ is top set, strong hand can bet

6.reason: On monotone board without flush, betting easily gets raised by flush hands

7.reason: Has nut flush draw, can bet as semi-bluff

8.reason: OOP on dynamic board, even AA should consider checking to protect range

9.reason: Dry A-high board, AA is top set, can bet

10.reason: Can't explain 'I'm betting because ___, after called I plan ___' = shouldn't bet

11.reason: On A-K-x board, KQ is second pair, can thin value bet

checkFirst.cardDesc: Get 10 consecutive 'should check' scenarios correct, build Check First habit
checkFirst.title: Check First Challenge
checkFirst.desc: Get {target} consecutive correct to pass. Wrong answer resets to zero!
checkFirst.hintAllCheck: Hint: Every question here, the correct answer is Check
checkFirst.muscleMemory: You've built Check First muscle memory!
checkFirst.rememberRule: Remember: Can't explain betting reason = shouldn't bet
checkFirst.question: Should this hand?

liveExploit.cardDesc: GTO vs live adjustment comparison, multiway pot strategy
liveExploit.selectTexture: Select a texture to view live exploit notes
liveExploit.liveAdjustQ: How should you adjust for live play?

0.explanation: Strong Ax can still value bet large in multiway

1.explanation: Cannot bluff multiway, give up air

2.explanation: Top pair can probe small, but don't bloat the pot

3.explanation: Mid pair too weak multiway, check for pot control

4.explanation: Nuts can bet large to build pot multiway

5.explanation: Multiway draws check is the better option

6.explanation: Connected low board overpair bets small for protection

7.explanation: Don't bluff multiway, just give up

8.explanation: Slow-playing nuts is pointless, bet for value directly

9.explanation: Multiway wet board AA is dangerous, check for pot control

10.explanation: Full house bets small to induce

0.explanation: Check-raise on ABB board = two pair or set, don't fight

1.action: Opponent river check-raises your triple barrel
1.explanation: River check-raise is almost always the real deal

3.action: Opponent suddenly increases bet size on turn
3.explanation: Sudden large bet = has a hand wants value

4.action: Fish player makes small river bet
4.explanation: Small bet = bluff myth or weak value, can raise

5.action: Opponent check-calls throughout then bets pot on river
5.explanation: This line is almost exclusively the nuts

6.action: Passive player suddenly 3-bets your turn bet
6.explanation: Passive player initiating aggression = very strong hand

7.action: Opponent checks flop, donk-bets pot on turn
7.explanation: Paired board delayed donk = usually trips

8.explanation: Quick call = draw or weak pair

9.explanation: Tank all-in = polarized, nuts or bluff

0.explanation: Small C-bet = weak hand probing, raise to push them out

1.leak: Opponent checks turn then bets big on river
1.explanation: This line has almost no bluffs, fold marginal hands

2.explanation: Can thin value bet more, they won't check-raise you

3.leak: Opponent always checks medium hands on river
3.explanation: Their check = marginal hand, you can thin value bet

4.explanation: Against non-folders only play for value, no bluffs

5.explanation: They bluff too much, call with wider range

6.leak: Opponent has Ax and never folds
6.explanation: They call too much, overbet value with nuts

range.selectToView: Select a position to view the range

equity.title: Equity Quiz
equity.description: Test your knowledge of preflop hand equities
equity.question: What's the approximate all-in equity for these two hands?

tips.title: Common Equity Rules
tips.coinflip: Pair vs Two Overcards ≈ 55% vs 45% (classic coinflip)
tips.domination: Dominated hands (e.g., AK vs AQ) ≈ 70% vs 30%

outs.title: Outs Quiz
outs.description: Test your ability to count outs on the flop
outs.question: How many outs does this draw have?
outs.tipCombo: Combo draws subtract overlapping cards (e.g., flush + straight)

ev.title: EV Quiz
ev.description: Test your pot odds and expected value calculations
ev.questionPotOdds: What equity do you need to call?
ev.questionEV: What is the EV of calling?
ev.questionImplied: Considering implied odds, should you call or fold?
ev.tipPotOdds: Pot Odds = Call Amount ÷ (Pot + Villain Bet + Call Amount)
ev.tipImplied: Implied odds consider chips you may win in future streets
ev.explainPotOdds: Calling {bet} into a pot of {total}, need {bet}/{total} = {result}% equity
ev.explainImplied: With deep stacks and strong draws, implied odds can make up for insufficient direct odds

logic.title: GTO Logic Quiz
logic.description: Test your understanding of GTO principles

exploit.title: Exploit Quiz
exploit.description: Learn to adjust GTO strategy based on opponent types
exploit.tip1: 1. Calling Stations: Never bluff, always value bet bigger
exploit.tip2: 2. Nits: Fold marginal hands to their aggression, steal more
exploit.tip3: 3. Aggro Fish: Trap with strong hands, reduce bluffs
exploit.tip4: 4. High Rake: Tighten ranges, avoid marginal spots

postflop.title: Postflop Street Practice
postflop.description: Practice GTO strategies for Flop C-bet, Turn Barrel, and River Decisions

cbet.title: Postflop C-bet Practice
cbet.description: Practice making correct C-bet decisions on different board textures
cbet.question: What's your play?
cbet.tip1: Dry boards (like A72r) are good for high-frequency small c-bets due to range advantage.
cbet.tip2: Wet boards (like JT9ss) require more caution - opponents have more strong hands and draws.
cbet.tip3: Consider your hand's equity and playability on this specific board.

turn.tip1: Turn continuation bets should consider range changes from flop action
turn.tip2: Good turn cards are usually high cards or cards that complete your draws
turn.tip3: Pot control checks are sometimes better than forcing barrels

river.tip1: River is the final decision point - no more improvement opportunities
river.tip2: Consider opponent's range: what hands call? what hands fold?
river.tip3: Blocker effects are crucial for river bluff decisions

postflop.sizingPrompt: You decided to bet — choose the correct size

pushFold.title: MTT Push/Fold Charts
pushFold.description: Nash equilibrium push/fold ranges for short-stacked MTT play
pushFold.pushDesc: Hands to shove all-in when short-stacked
pushFold.defenseDesc: Hands to call when facing an all-in
pushFold.huDesc: Heads up push/fold ranges for final table and HU situations
pushFold.tip1: The shorter your stack, the wider you should push. At 3bb, shove almost any two cards.
pushFold.tip2: Later positions can push wider. BTN and SB are prime stealing spots.
pushFold.tip3: Consider pot odds when defending. BB should call wide vs SB shove.

icm.title: ICM Calculator
icm.description: Calculate real chip values in tournament scenarios
icm.tip1: ICM considers tournament payout structure - chip value is non-linear.
icm.tip2: Big stacks have diminishing marginal value, small stacks have high survival value.
icm.tip3: ICM pressure is highest near the bubble and at final tables.
